Canonical Distributions

January 20, 2025

Comprehensive table comparing canonical distribution and its variants in terms of their modeling objectives, inputs/outputs, and probability distribution forms or PMFs

DistributionModeling ObjectiveInputsOutputsProbability Form or PMF
Canonical Distribution (Boltzmann)Models the probability of a system being in a specific state based on energy.Energy levels Ei, inverse temperature β=1kBT.Probabilities of states.P(i)=e−βEiZ,Z=∑je−βEj.
Multinomial DistributionModels counts across multiple discrete categories over N trials.Probabilities of categories pi, number of trials N.Joint probabilities of counts across categories.P(k1,…,kn)=N!k1!⋯kn!∏i=1npiki,∑i=1npi=1.
Softmax DistributionConverts logits (scores) into probabilities for classification tasks.Logits zi (unnormalized scores).Probabilities for each category.P(i)=ezi∑jezj.
Binomial DistributionModels the number of successes in N Bernoulli trials.Probability of success p, number of trials N.Probability of k successes.P(X=k)=(Nk)pk(1−p)N−k.
Geometric DistributionModels the number of trials needed for the first success.Probability of success p.Probability of trials until first success.P(X=k)=(1−p)k−1p,k≥1.
Poisson DistributionModels the number of events in a fixed interval with constant rate.Average rate λ.Probability of k events.P(X=k)=λke−λk!,k≥0.
Normal (Gaussian) DistributionModels continuous data clustering around a mean.Mean μ, standard deviation σ.Continuous probability density.P(x)=12πσ2e−(x−μ)22σ2.
Exponential DistributionModels the time between events in a Poisson process.Rate λ (inverse mean).Probability of time t.P(T=t)=λe−λt,t≥0.
Categorical DistributionModels a single draw from discrete categories.Probabilities p1,p2,…,pn.Probabilities for n categories.P(X=i)=pi,∑i=1npi=1.
